text.p: Following are some of the top headlines in leading Italian newspapers.

* The lower house of parliament's labour commission on Wednesday approved the government's controversial labour bill hours after the same package had been defeated by separate parliamentary commission in which hard left Communist Refoundation abstained (all).
* Communist Refoundation party leader Fausto Bertinotti reaffirmed the party's stand that pension cuts should be the last step to be taken in welfare state reform (all).
* A report by national statistics institute Istat showed Italy had a 3.373 trillion lire trade surplus with non-European countries in March (all).

* Industrialists' organisation Confindustria said Italy's gross domestic product may register around zero growth in the first quarter of 1997 and it remained pessimistic about the economic outlook. Confindustria added that inflation might fall close to 1.5 percent year-on-year this month from 1.7 percent in April (all).
* Italy's largest quoted retailer Rinascente closed down 8.25 percent on the Milan stock exchange after the group announced an accord with France's Auchan and a capital increase (all).
* Assogestioni, the industry body, said Italian investment funds had a net inflow of 4.964 trillion lire in April compared with a net inflow of 5.99 trillion lire in March (all).
* Franco Tato, managing director of electricity utility Enel, said in an interview that after the link-up with state-controlled energy group Eni Enel was ready to find new allies (Sole 24 Ore).
* Italy and the European Commission tried to iron out differences about a plan to rescue loss-making airline Alitalia, but a final decision is not expected before the end of June (all).
** Reuters has not verified these stories and cannot vouch for their accuracy.
